div1.head: Military Orders for James Carroll, October 10, 1900
div1.p: Carroll

OCT 25 1900
ROLLS DIVISION.
RECD, OCT 20 1900

FROM THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES
Vol 175 A 1900

SPECIAL ORDERS, }
No 178. }

HEADQUARTERS DIVISION OF CUBA,
Havana, October 10, 1900.

1. Leave of absence for twenty (20) days, with permis-
sion to go beyond the limits of the Division, is hereby
granted 2d Lieutenant Evan H. Humphrey, 7th Cavalry,
Acting Assistant Quartermaster at these Headquarters.

2. Leave of absence for twenty (20) days on surgeon's
certificate of disability, with permission to go beyond the
limits of the Division, is hereby granted to Acting Assistant
Surgeon James Carroll, U. S. Army.

3. Leave of absence for two (2) months, with permission
to go beyond the limits of the Division, is hereby granted
to Captain William A. Phillips, 10th Infantry.

4. Leave of absence for twenty (20) days, is hereby
granted 2d Lieutenant C. F. Armistead, 2d Artillery, to take
effect upon the expiration of the present sick leave granted
him in paragraph 1, Special Orders No. 49, current series,
Department of Western Cuba.

5. Private Harrg L. Whitaker, Troop K, 7th Cavalry,
having been tried by a general court-martial convened at
Columbia Barracks, Cuba, and found guilty of suffering
two prisoners to escape, to the prejudice of good order and
military discipline, evidence of three (3) previous convic-
tions having been considered by the court, was sentenced
“To be confined at hard labor, under charge of the post guard,
for six (6) months.”

In the foregoing case of private Harry L. Whitaker,
Troop K, 7th Cavalry, the proceedings are approved. The
findings of the court and sentence are disapproved, the tes-
timony introduced by the prosecution, appearing in the
record, not warranting a finding of guilty of the charge,
but rather sustaining the plea of not guilty by the accused.

If the court was cognizant of other facts in regard to the
escape of the prisoners which would substantiate the find-
ings and prove the culpability of the accused, the record
fails to make mention thereof.

Private Whitaker will be released from confinement and
restored to duty with his troop.

6. Private Patrick Canning, Battery H, 2d Artillery, hav-
ing been tried by a general court-martial convened at Santa
Clara Battery, Havana, Cuba, and found guilty of absence
without leave, in violation of the 32d Article of War;
absence from guard, in violation of the 33d Article of War,
and conduct to the prejudice of good order and military
discipline, in violation of the 62d Article of War, evidence
of six (6) previous convictions having been considered by
the court, was sentenced “To forfeit ten (10) dollars per
month for three (3) months.”

The sentence is confirmed to date October 8, 1900, and
will be duly executed. The prisoner will be released and
restored to duty with his battery.

7. Private John Walton, Troop I, 2d Cavalry, having
been tried by a general court-martial convened at Hamilton
Barracks, Cuba, and found guilty of sleeping on post, in
violation of the 39th Article of War, was sentenced “To be
confined at hard labor, under charge of the post guard, for three
(3) months, and to forfeit ten (10) dollars per month for the same
period.”

The sentence is confirmed to date October 8, 1900, and
will be duly executed at the post where his troop is stationed.

8. Private George W. Van Wyck, Company G, 10th
Infantry, having been tried by a general court-martial
convened at Rowell Barracks, Pasa Caballos, Cuba, and
found guilty of breaking arrest, in violation of the 62d
Article of War, evidence of seven (7) previous convictions
having been considered by the court, was sentenced “To be
dishonorably discharged the service of the United States, forfeiting
all pay and allowances due him, and to be confined at hard labor
at such place as the reviewing authority may direct, for the period
of three (3) months.”

The sentence is confirmed to date October 8, 1900, and
will be duly executed at Rowell Barracks, Cuba.
BY COMMAND OF MAJOR GENERAL WOOD:

H. L. SCOTT,
Adjutant General.
